content.description:
Fun crux moves. 



Start between the Moon and Uranus up the somewhat smooth.

Bolted 2020.

Easy first clip, crux between bolts 3 to 4. Once on arete, fun finish to top. 



Far left on the Backside crag, but not as left as the South facing slab area. CP is just left of the small prow. 

New Stainless Steel bolts and hangers as of apprx. 2020.

One of the easier lines for beginners or climbers wanting a good warm-up. It was bolted very well with the intention of making it safe for new leaders to practice clipping etc. Watch the first few bolts during your clipping as they are close enough where z-clipping is possible for long-armed climbers. One of the longer routes of the Backside. 



It is the second most far right climb at the Backside and left of 'Turn the Other Cheek'. Yet starts just right of a  mossy cliff incision.

SS Bolts (2020) with chain anchors.

Hand crack into slab chimney (first ascensionist unknown). This trad climb is on the small feature right of 'Twerkin Man'. Cleaning pending. 



Small slab dihedral natural protection climb which starts upon the 'rock-patio' lace up area. Sits right of the small prow and just left of 'Twerkin Man'. 

Traditional

Info lacking to date. Development crew needs to inspect the 2 bolts on route set many years ago. The trad placements look tricky from ground. A route review, cleaning, and revamp may be required in summer 2023. 



Backside crag center to center-left. Smooth walled face with small sections of crack where placements may be set. 

Mixed: small cracks and 2 bolts.

Some interesting moves up the 1st 2-3 bolts on arete/dihedral feature until a harder clip and potential crux appears. Older route which has was retro bolted and cleaned in 2020. 



Arete/Dihedral feature to the right of 'Nookie for Rockstars'.

Bolts

The moves are very specific to exact holds. Route gets nicer as you figure out the lower sequence. 



The route is right of 'Tainted Love' and named after the mid-route 'Nook' in the wall. After 2-3 bolts, you climb past that nook and slightly left around the bulge. 

Stainless Steel bolts (2020) with chain anchors.

After ascending the alpine style 5.5-ish rampway to get to the crux section, then climb the dihedral with trad gear to the top-out. The crux moves are really fun for the grade, but unfortunately they are short lived and last for arounf 3-5 stemming style moves. This climb can be set up as a top-rope from the top but the middle (of 3) of the upper anchors is highly recommended since the far laft anchor runs the top-rope over a somewhat sharp edge; if the middle anchor is set up for TR and you rappel down, you can place a 1 or 2 inch cam in the climb to help keep TR climbers on the route (ie directionals). 

If leading, the beta is to bring up at least one, #2 (BD) cam, and one #0.75 cam. A single bolt was placed at the top of the 5.6 rampway to prevent the event of 'unzippering' from the belayer up of the trad gear should a lead climber fall. No natural protection is available along the rampway. If you wish to climb it in 'pure trad' style and avoid the bolt, bring up 2 of your smallest micro-cams and perhaps the smallest 2 nuts and there are some shallow micro cracks you may try to utilize; but don't fall as per the 'unzippering' note above.



Farthest climb at climbers-left at the whole Backside crag; left of 'Sleeping Booty'. 

Pure Trad= #2 cam, #.75 cam, try smallest micro cams // or 1 low bolt and #2 & #.75 cams.

Easier climbing at start and end of climb with an acute crux mid-way up. A very specific crux sequence is forced enroute but fun to execute once you figure it out. At top of crag, 2 anchors may be chosen from to set up a TR; the upper developers anchor is safer/quicker to set up but will produce more rope drag on TR belaying. The lower "lead intended anchor' may be reached from the top edge, but dropping down onto it without utilizing the upper development anchor could be more sketchy. No matter the way you set this route up, the crux moves are worth it and the easier parts should be fun for beginners and a good warm up for mid-range climbers. 



This route is on the Backside's South Wall (farthest climbers' left wall) and it is just to the right of Rumplestiltskin.

4 bolts, then chains for anchor.

Climb up the subtle arete, clipping bolts. 



This route is right of 'Twerking Man' and the little ground-based rock 'patio' area where people sit and put their shoes on. Just right of a small incision in the crag and on a subtle arete. 

Bolts

After the very specific foot sequence off the ground to a nice jug, the crux is roughly 3-4 bolts up where there's a nice forced movement. 



As of 2022, this is the farthest right climb at the Backside; right of the easier climb and right of that crag wall's in-cut; on the face. 

SS bolts (2020), Chain anchors.

Stepping up from the 'rock patio' at the crag's base, climb the bolted line straight up this small wall's center. The line has been considered by some to be somewhat contrived with the temptation to climb up left in that old trad line, but it's cleaner to stay with the bolts. One stretch appears run out between bolts 2 & 3 but the climbing is easier once you get there; if nervous you could probably find a small cam to fill in the gap. Chain anchors.



This line is right of the small prow, right of the old trad line in the dihedral, yet left of the subtle arete which 'Tainted Love' is one. Sandwiched in the center of a small wall portion and above that little 'rock patio'. 

Bolted 2020 (can bring 1 small cam if needed)

Route needs cleaning and development considerations; TBD 2023. 



Obscure slab-crack between the prow and 'Twerkin Man'. 

Gear.

Retro bolted and cleaned in 2020. 



Furthest route on this wall before the old growth fir tree and crag wall incut/gully feature and the pond wall.

Bolts

The Backside's routes are shorter than the frontside routes. Frontside is more classic, but when the frontside is packed with people and top ropes hangin on every line, we suggest checking out the Backside and the range of grades found there. Natural amenity is more pristine back there with old growth Douglas-fir trees and the occasional Great Horned owl. You will probably have the area to yourself and choice of any line. Fall, Late summer, or spring are the optimal times to climb here as the mosquitoes may be worse in peak summer than found at Frontside. The developer's favorite routes so far include 'Turn the Other Cheek', 'Brace Yourself', and 'Cutie Patootie' to date.
